member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Constructor.
member.remarks: The following parameters can be set: - proof (Boolean) Enable proof generation - debug_ref_count (Boolean) Enable debug support for Z3_ast reference counting - trace (Boolean) Tracing support for VCC - trace_file_name (String) Trace out file for VCC traces - timeout (unsigned) default timeout (in milliseconds) used for solvers - well_sorted_check type checker - auto_config use heuristics to automatically select solver and configure it - model model generation for solvers, this parameter can be overwritten when creating a solver - model_validate validate models produced by solvers - unsat_core unsat-core generation for solvers, this parameter can be overwritten when creating a solver Note that in previous versions of Z3, this constructor was also used to set global and module parameters. For this purpose we should now use

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkInt2Real(Microsoft.Z3.IntExpr)
member.summary: Coerce an integer to a real.
member.remarks:
There is also a converse operation exposed. It follows the semantics prescribed by the SMT-LIB standard.
You can take the floor of a real by creating an auxiliary integer Term k and and asserting MakeInt2Real(k) <= t1 < MkInt2Real(k)+1. The argument must be of integer sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVUDiv(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Unsigned division.
member.remarks: It is defined as the floor of t1/t2 if \c t2 is different from zero. If t2 is zero, then the result is undefined. The arguments must have the same bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVSDiv(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Signed division.
member.remarks:
It is defined in the following way:
- The \c floor of t1/t2 if \c t2 is different from zero, and t1*t2 >= 0.
- The \c ceiling of t1/t2 if \c t2 is different from zero, and t1*t2 < 0.
If t2 is zero, then the result is undefined. The arguments must have the same bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVURem(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Unsigned remainder.
member.remarks: It is defined as t1 - (t1 /u t2) * t2, where /u represents unsigned division. If t2 is zero, then the result is undefined. The arguments must have the same bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVSRem(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Signed remainder.
member.remarks:
It is defined as t1 - (t1 /s t2) * t2, where /s represents signed division. The most significant bit (sign) of the result is equal to the most significant bit of \c t1.
If t2 is zero, then the result is undefined. The arguments must have the same bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVSMod(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Two's complement signed remainder (sign follows divisor).
member.remarks: If t2 is zero, then the result is undefined. The arguments must have the same bit-vector sort.

member.summary: Bit-vector extraction.
member.remarks: Extract the bits down to from a bitvector of size m to yield a new bitvector of size n, where n = high - low + 1. The argument must have a bit-vector sort.

member.remarks: Sign-extends the given bit-vector to the (signed) equivalent bitvector of size m+i, where \c m is the size of the given bit-vector. The argument must have a bit-vector sort.

member.remarks: Extend the given bit-vector with zeros to the (unsigned) equivalent bitvector of size m+i, where \c m is the size of the given bit-vector. The argument must have a bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVSHL(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Shift left.
member.remarks:
It is equivalent to multiplication by 2^x where \c x is the value of .
NB. The semantics of shift operations varies between environments. This definition does not necessarily capture directly the semantics of the programming language or assembly architecture you are modeling.
The arguments must have a bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVLSHR(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Logical shift right
member.remarks:
It is equivalent to unsigned division by 2^x where \c x is the value of .
NB. The semantics of shift operations varies between environments. This definition does not necessarily capture directly the semantics of the programming language or assembly architecture you are modeling.
The arguments must have a bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBVASHR(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Arithmetic shift right
member.remarks:
It is like logical shift right except that the most significant bits of the result always copy the most significant bit of the second argument.
NB. The semantics of shift operations varies between environments. This definition does not necessarily capture directly the semantics of the programming language or assembly architecture you are modeling.
The arguments must have a bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkInt2BV(System.UInt32,Microsoft.Z3.IntExpr)
member.summary: Create an bit bit-vector from the integer argument .
member.remarks:
NB. This function is essentially treated as uninterpreted. So you cannot expect Z3 to precisely reflect the semantics of this function when solving constraints with this function.
The argument must be of integer sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkBV2Int(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create an integer from the bit-vector argument .
member.remarks:
If \c is_signed is false, then the bit-vector \c t1 is treated as unsigned. So the result is non-negative and in the range [0..2^N-1], where N are the number of bits in . If \c is_signed is true, \c t1 is treated as a signed bit-vector.
NB. This function is essentially treated as uninterpreted. So you cannot expect Z3 to precisely reflect the semantics of this function when solving constraints with this function.
The argument must be of bit-vector sort.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkSelect(Microsoft.Z3.ArrayExpr,Microsoft.Z3.Expr)
member.summary: Array read.
member.remarks:
The argument a is the array and i is the index of the array that gets read.
The node a must have an array sort [domain -> range], and i must have the sort domain. The sort of the result is range.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkSelect(Microsoft.Z3.ArrayExpr,Microsoft.Z3.Expr[])
member.summary: Array read.
member.remarks:
The argument a is the array and args are the indices of the array that gets read.
The node a must have an array sort [domain1,..,domaink -> range], and args must have the sort domain1,..,domaink. The sort of the result is range.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkStore(Microsoft.Z3.ArrayExpr,Microsoft.Z3.Expr,Microsoft.Z3.Expr)
member.summary: Array update.
member.remarks: The node a must have an array sort [domain -> range], i must have sort domain, v must have sort range. The sort of the result is [domain -> range]. The semantics of this function is given by the theory of arrays described in the SMT-LIB standard. See http://smtlib.org for more details. The result of this function is an array that is equal to a (with respect to select) on all indices except for i, where it maps to v (and the select of a with respect to i may be a different value).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkStore(Microsoft.Z3.ArrayExpr,Microsoft.Z3.Expr[],Microsoft.Z3.Expr)
member.summary: Array update.
member.remarks: The node a must have an array sort [domain1,..,domaink -> range], args must have sort domain1,..,domaink, v must have sort range. The sort of the result is [domain -> range]. The semantics of this function is given by the theory of arrays described in the SMT-LIB standard. See http://smtlib.org for more details. The result of this function is an array that is equal to a (with respect to select) on all indices except for args, where it maps to v (and the select of a with respect to args may be a different value).

member.summary: Create a constant array.
member.remarks: The resulting term is an array, such that a selecton an arbitrary index produces the value v.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkMap(Microsoft.Z3.FuncDecl,Microsoft.Z3.ArrayExpr[])
member.summary: Maps f on the argument arrays.
member.remarks: Each element of args must be of an array sort [domain_i -> range_i]. The function declaration f must have type range_1 .. range_n -> range. v must have sort range. The sort of the result is [domain_i -> range].

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkForall(Microsoft.Z3.Sort[],Microsoft.Z3.Symbol[],Microsoft.Z3.Expr,System.UInt32,Microsoft.Z3.Pattern[],Microsoft.Z3.Expr[],Microsoft.Z3.Symbol,Microsoft.Z3.Symbol)
member.summary: Create a universal Quantifier.
member.remarks: Creates a forall formula, where is the weight, is an array of patterns, is an array with the sorts of the bound variables, is an array with the 'names' of the bound variables, and is the body of the quantifier. Quantifiers are associated with weights indicating the importance of using the quantifier during instantiation. Note that the bound variables are de-Bruijn indices created using . Z3 applies the convention that the last element in and refers to the variable with index 0, the second to last element of and refers to the variable with index 1, etc.
member.param: the sorts of the bound variables.
quantifiers are associated with weights indicating the importance of using the quantifier during instantiation. By default, pass the weight 0.
array containing the patterns created using MkPattern.
array containing the anti-patterns created using MkPattern.
optional symbol to track skolem constants.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Context.PrintMode
member.summary: Selects the format used for pretty-printing expressions.
member.remarks: The default mode for pretty printing expressions is to produce SMT-LIB style output where common subexpressions are printed at each occurrence. The mode is called Z3_PRINT_SMTLIB_FULL. To print shared common subexpressions only once, use the Z3_PRINT_LOW_LEVEL mode. To print in way that conforms to SMT-LIB standards and uses let expressions to share common sub-expressions use Z3_PRINT_SMTLIB_COMPLIANT.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFP(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr)
member.summary: Create an expression of FloatingPoint sort from three bit-vector expressions.
member.remarks: This is the operator named `fp' in the SMT FP theory definition. Note that sgn is required to be a bit-vector of size 1. Significand and exponent are required to be greater than 1 and 2 respectively. The FloatingPoint sort of the resulting expression is automatically determined from the bit-vector sizes of the arguments.
member.param: bit-vector term (of size 1) representing the sign.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToFP(Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPSort)
member.summary: Conversion of a single IEEE 754-2008 bit-vector into a floating-point number.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of a bit-vector term bv to a floating-point term of sort s. The bit-vector size of bv (m) must be equal to ebits+sbits of s. The format of the bit-vector is as defined by the IEEE 754-2008 interchange format.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToFP(Microsoft.Z3.FPRMExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPSort)
member.summary: Conversion of a FloatingPoint term into another term of different FloatingPoint sort.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of a floating-point term t to a floating-point term of sort s. If necessary, the result will be rounded according to rounding mode rm.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToFP(Microsoft.Z3.FPRMExpr,Microsoft.Z3.RealExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPSort)
member.summary: Conversion of a term of real sort into a term of FloatingPoint sort.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of term t of real sort into a floating-point term of sort s. If necessary, the result will be rounded according to rounding mode rm.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToFP(Microsoft.Z3.FPRMExpr,Microsoft.Z3.BitVecExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPSort,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Conversion of a 2's complement signed bit-vector term into a term of FloatingPoint sort.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of the bit-vector term t into a floating-point term of sort s. The bit-vector t is taken to be in signed 2's complement format (when signed==true, otherwise unsigned). If necessary, the result will be rounded according to rounding mode rm.
member.param: flag indicating whether t is interpreted as signed or unsigned bit-vector.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToFP(Microsoft.Z3.FPSort,Microsoft.Z3.FPRMExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPExpr)
member.summary: Conversion of a floating-point number to another FloatingPoint sort s.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of a floating-point term t to a different FloatingPoint sort s. If necessary, rounding according to rm is applied.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToBV(Microsoft.Z3.FPRMExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPExpr,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Conversion of a floating-point term into a bit-vector.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of the floating-point term t into a bit-vector term of size sz in 2's complement format (signed when signed==true). If necessary, the result will be rounded according to rounding mode rm.
member.param: Indicates whether the result is a signed or unsigned bit-vector.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToReal(Microsoft.Z3.FPExpr)
member.summary: Conversion of a floating-point term into a real-numbered term.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of the floating-point term t into a real number. Note that this type of conversion will often result in non-linear constraints over real terms.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToIEEEBV(Microsoft.Z3.FPExpr)
member.summary: Conversion of a floating-point term into a bit-vector term in IEEE 754-2008 format.
member.remarks: The size of the resulting bit-vector is automatically determined. Note that IEEE 754-2008 allows multiple different representations of NaN. This conversion knows only one NaN and it will always produce the same bit-vector representation of that NaN.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.MkFPToFP(Microsoft.Z3.FPRMExpr,Microsoft.Z3.IntExpr,Microsoft.Z3.RealExpr,Microsoft.Z3.FPSort)
member.summary: Conversion of a real-sorted significand and an integer-sorted exponent into a term of FloatingPoint sort.
member.remarks: Produces a term that represents the conversion of sig * 2^exp into a floating-point term of sort s. If necessary, the result will be rounded according to rounding mode rm.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.WrapAST(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Wraps an AST.
member.remarks: This function is used for transitions between native and managed objects. Note that must be a native object obtained from Z3 (e.g., through ) and that it must have a correct reference count (see e.g., .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Context.UnwrapAST(Microsoft.Z3.AST)
member.summary: Unwraps an AST.
member.remarks: This function is used for transitions between native and managed objects. It returns the native pointer to the AST. Note that AST objects are reference counted and unwrapping an AST disables automatic reference counting, i.e., all references to the IntPtr that is returned must be handled externally and through native calls (see e.g., ).

member.remarks: The list of all configuration parameters can be obtained using the Z3 executable: z3.exe -p Only a few configuration parameters are mutable once the context is created. An exception is thrown when trying to modify an immutable parameter.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.Substitute(Microsoft.Z3.Expr[],Microsoft.Z3.Expr[])
member.summary: Substitute every occurrence of from[i] in the expression with to[i], for i smaller than num_exprs.
member.remarks: The result is the new expression. The arrays from and to must have size num_exprs. For every i smaller than num_exprs, we must have that sort of from[i] must be equal to sort of to[i].

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.Substitute(Microsoft.Z3.Expr,Microsoft.Z3.Expr)
member.summary: Substitute every occurrence of from in the expression with to.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.SubstituteVars(Microsoft.Z3.Expr[])
member.summary: Substitute the free variables in the expression with the expressions in
member.remarks: For every i smaller than num_exprs, the variable with de-Bruijn index i is replaced with term to[i].

member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a bit-vector rotate right

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsBVRotateLeftExtended
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a bit-vector rotate left (extended)
member.remarks: Similar to Z3_OP_ROTATE_LEFT, but it is a binary operator instead of a parametric one.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsBVRotateRightExtended
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a bit-vector rotate right (extended)
member.remarks: Similar to Z3_OP_ROTATE_RIGHT, but it is a binary operator instead of a parametric one.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsIntToBV
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a coercion from integer to bit-vector
member.remarks: This function is not supported by the decision procedures. Only the most rudimentary simplification rules are applied to this function.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsBVToInt
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a coercion from bit-vector to integer
member.remarks: This function is not supported by the decision procedures. Only the most rudimentary simplification rules are applied to this function.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsBVCarry
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a bit-vector carry
member.remarks: Compute the carry bit in a full-adder. The meaning is given by the equivalence (carry l1 l2 l3) <=> (or (and l1 l2) (and l1 l3) (and l2 l3)))

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsBVXOR3
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a bit-vector ternary XOR
member.remarks: The meaning is given by the equivalence (xor3 l1 l2 l3) <=> (xor (xor l1 l2) l3)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsLabel
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a label (used by the Boogie Verification condition generator).
member.remarks: The label has two parameters, a string and a Boolean polarity. It takes one argument, a formula.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsLabelLit
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a label literal (used by the Boogie Verification condition generator).
member.remarks: A label literal has a set of string parameters. It takes no arguments.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsString
member.summary: Check whether expression is a string constant.
member.returns: a Boolean

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.String
member.summary: Retrieve string corresponding to string constant.
member.remarks: the expression should be a string constant, (IsString should be true).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsConcat
member.summary: Check whether expression is a concatenation.
member.returns: a Boolean

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsPrefix
member.summary: Check whether expression is a prefix.
member.returns: a Boolean

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsSuffix

member.returns: a Boolean

member.returns: a Boolean

member.returns: a Boolean

member.returns: a Boolean

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsIndex
member.summary: Check whether expression is a sequence index.
member.returns: a Boolean

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsOEQ
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a binary equivalence modulo namings.
member.remarks: This binary predicate is used in proof terms. It captures equisatisfiability and equivalence modulo renamings.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofTrue
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a Proof for the expression 'true'.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofAsserted
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for a fact asserted by the user.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofGoal
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for a fact (tagged as goal) asserted by the user.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofModusPonens
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is proof via modus ponens
member.remarks: Given a proof for p and a proof for (implies p q), produces a proof for q. T1: p T2: (implies p q) [mp T1 T2]: q The second antecedents may also be a proof for (iff p q).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofReflexivity
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for (R t t), where R is a reflexive relation.
member.remarks: This proof object has no antecedents. The only reflexive relations that are used are equivalence modulo namings, equality and equivalence. That is, R is either '~', '=' or 'iff'.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofSymmetry
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is proof by symmetricity of a relation
member.remarks: Given an symmetric relation R and a proof for (R t s), produces a proof for (R s t). T1: (R t s) [symmetry T1]: (R s t) T1 is the antecedent of this proof object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofTransitivity
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by transitivity of a relation
member.remarks: Given a transitive relation R, and proofs for (R t s) and (R s u), produces a proof for (R t u). T1: (R t s) T2: (R s u) [trans T1 T2]: (R t u)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofTransitivityStar
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by condensed transitivity of a relation
member.remarks:
Condensed transitivity proof. It combines several symmetry and transitivity proofs. Example: T1: (R a b) T2: (R c b) T3: (R c d) [trans* T1 T2 T3]: (R a d) R must be a symmetric and transitive relation.
Assuming that this proof object is a proof for (R s t), then a proof checker must check if it is possible to prove (R s t) using the antecedents, symmetry and transitivity. That is, if there is a path from s to t, if we view every antecedent (R a b) as an edge between a and b.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofMonotonicity
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a monotonicity proof object.
member.remarks: T1: (R t_1 s_1) ... Tn: (R t_n s_n) [monotonicity T1 ... Tn]: (R (f t_1 ... t_n) (f s_1 ... s_n)) Remark: if t_i == s_i, then the antecedent Ti is suppressed. That is, reflexivity proofs are suppressed to save space.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofQuantIntro
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a quant-intro proof
member.remarks: Given a proof for (~ p q), produces a proof for (~ (forall (x) p) (forall (x) q)). T1: (~ p q) [quant-intro T1]: (~ (forall (x) p) (forall (x) q))

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofDistributivity
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a distributivity proof object.
member.remarks:
Given that f (= or) distributes over g (= and), produces a proof for (= (f a (g c d)) (g (f a c) (f a d))) If f and g are associative, this proof also justifies the following equality: (= (f (g a b) (g c d)) (g (f a c) (f a d) (f b c) (f b d))) where each f and g can have arbitrary number of arguments.
This proof object has no antecedents. Remark. This rule is used by the CNF conversion pass and instantiated by f = or, and g = and.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofAndElimination
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by elimination of AND
member.remarks: Given a proof for (and l_1 ... l_n), produces a proof for l_i T1: (and l_1 ... l_n) [and-elim T1]: l_i

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofOrElimination
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by elimination of not-or
member.remarks: Given a proof for (not (or l_1 ... l_n)), produces a proof for (not l_i). T1: (not (or l_1 ... l_n)) [not-or-elim T1]: (not l_i)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofRewrite
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by rewriting
member.remarks:
A proof for a local rewriting step (= t s). The head function symbol of t is interpreted.
This proof object has no antecedents. The conclusion of a rewrite rule is either an equality (= t s), an equivalence (iff t s), or equi-satisfiability (~ t s). Remark: if f is bool, then = is iff.
Examples: (= (+ x 0) x) (= (+ x 1 2) (+ 3 x)) (iff (or x false) x)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofRewriteStar
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by rewriting
member.remarks: A proof for rewriting an expression t into an expression s. This proof object can have n antecedents. The antecedents are proofs for equalities used as substitution rules. The object is used in a few cases: - When applying contextual simplification (CONTEXT_SIMPLIFIER=true) - When converting bit-vectors to Booleans (BIT2BOOL=true)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofPullQuant
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for pulling quantifiers out.
member.remarks: A proof for (iff (f (forall (x) q(x)) r) (forall (x) (f (q x) r))). This proof object has no antecedents.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofPushQuant
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for pushing quantifiers in.
member.remarks: A proof for: (iff (forall (x_1 ... x_m) (and p_1[x_1 ... x_m] ... p_n[x_1 ... x_m])) (and (forall (x_1 ... x_m) p_1[x_1 ... x_m]) ... (forall (x_1 ... x_m) p_n[x_1 ... x_m]))) This proof object has no antecedents

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofElimUnusedVars
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for elimination of unused variables.
member.remarks:
A proof for (iff (forall (x_1 ... x_n y_1 ... y_m) p[x_1 ... x_n]) (forall (x_1 ... x_n) p[x_1 ... x_n]))
It is used to justify the elimination of unused variables. This proof object has no antecedents.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofDER
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for destructive equality resolution
member.remarks:
A proof for destructive equality resolution: (iff (forall (x) (or (not (= x t)) P[x])) P[t]) if x does not occur in t.
This proof object has no antecedents.
Several variables can be eliminated simultaneously.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofQuantInst
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for quantifier instantiation
member.remarks: A proof of (or (not (forall (x) (P x))) (P a))

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofHypothesis
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a hypothesis marker.
member.remarks: Mark a hypothesis in a natural deduction style proof.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofLemma
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by lemma
member.remarks:
T1: false [lemma T1]: (or (not l_1) ... (not l_n))
This proof object has one antecedent: a hypothetical proof for false. It converts the proof in a proof for (or (not l_1) ... (not l_n)), when T1 contains the hypotheses: l_1, ..., l_n.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofUnitResolution
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by unit resolution
member.remarks: T1: (or l_1 ... l_n l_1' ... l_m') T2: (not l_1) ... T(n+1): (not l_n) [unit-resolution T1 ... T(n+1)]: (or l_1' ... l_m')

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofIFFTrue
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by iff-true
member.remarks: T1: p [iff-true T1]: (iff p true)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofIFFFalse
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by iff-false
member.remarks: T1: (not p) [iff-false T1]: (iff p false)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofCommutativity
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by commutativity
member.remarks:
[comm]: (= (f a b) (f b a))
f is a commutative operator.
This proof object has no antecedents. Remark: if f is bool, then = is iff.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofDefAxiom
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for Tseitin-like axioms
member.remarks:
Proof object used to justify Tseitin's like axioms:
(or (not (and p q)) p) (or (not (and p q)) q) (or (not (and p q r)) p) (or (not (and p q r)) q) (or (not (and p q r)) r) ... (or (and p q) (not p) (not q)) (or (not (or p q)) p q) (or (or p q) (not p)) (or (or p q) (not q)) (or (not (iff p q)) (not p) q) (or (not (iff p q)) p (not q)) (or (iff p q) (not p) (not q)) (or (iff p q) p q) (or (not (ite a b c)) (not a) b) (or (not (ite a b c)) a c) (or (ite a b c) (not a) (not b)) (or (ite a b c) a (not c)) (or (not (not a)) (not a)) (or (not a) a)
This proof object has no antecedents. Note: all axioms are propositional tautologies. Note also that 'and' and 'or' can take multiple arguments. You can recover the propositional tautologies by unfolding the Boolean connectives in the axioms a small bounded number of steps (=3).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofDefIntro
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for introduction of a name
member.remarks:
Introduces a name for a formula/term. Suppose e is an expression with free variables x, and def-intro introduces the name n(x). The possible cases are:
When e is of Boolean type: [def-intro]: (and (or n (not e)) (or (not n) e))
or: [def-intro]: (or (not n) e) when e only occurs positively.
When e is of the form (ite cond th el): [def-intro]: (and (or (not cond) (= n th)) (or cond (= n el)))
Otherwise: [def-intro]: (= n e)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofApplyDef
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for application of a definition
member.remarks: [apply-def T1]: F ~ n F is 'equivalent' to n, given that T1 is a proof that n is a name for F.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofIFFOEQ
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof iff-oeq
member.remarks: T1: (iff p q) [iff~ T1]: (~ p q)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofNNFPos
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for a positive NNF step
member.remarks:
Proof for a (positive) NNF step. Example:
T1: (not s_1) ~ r_1 T2: (not s_2) ~ r_2 T3: s_1 ~ r_1' T4: s_2 ~ r_2' [nnf-pos T1 T2 T3 T4]: (~ (iff s_1 s_2) (and (or r_1 r_2') (or r_1' r_2)))
The negation normal form steps NNF_POS and NNF_NEG are used in the following cases: (a) When creating the NNF of a positive force quantifier. The quantifier is retained (unless the bound variables are eliminated). Example T1: q ~ q_new [nnf-pos T1]: (~ (forall (x T) q) (forall (x T) q_new))
(b) When recursively creating NNF over Boolean formulas, where the top-level connective is changed during NNF conversion. The relevant Boolean connectives for NNF_POS are 'implies', 'iff', 'xor', 'ite'. NNF_NEG furthermore handles the case where negation is pushed over Boolean connectives 'and' and 'or'.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofNNFNeg
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for a negative NNF step
member.remarks:
Proof for a (negative) NNF step. Examples:
T1: (not s_1) ~ r_1 ... Tn: (not s_n) ~ r_n [nnf-neg T1 ... Tn]: (not (and s_1 ... s_n)) ~ (or r_1 ... r_n) and T1: (not s_1) ~ r_1 ... Tn: (not s_n) ~ r_n [nnf-neg T1 ... Tn]: (not (or s_1 ... s_n)) ~ (and r_1 ... r_n) and T1: (not s_1) ~ r_1 T2: (not s_2) ~ r_2 T3: s_1 ~ r_1' T4: s_2 ~ r_2' [nnf-neg T1 T2 T3 T4]: (~ (not (iff s_1 s_2)) (and (or r_1 r_2) (or r_1' r_2')))

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofSkolemize
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for a Skolemization step
member.remarks:
Proof for:
[sk]: (~ (not (forall x (p x y))) (not (p (sk y) y))) [sk]: (~ (exists x (p x y)) (p (sk y) y))
This proof object has no antecedents.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofModusPonensOEQ
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof by modus ponens for equi-satisfiability.
member.remarks: Modus ponens style rule for equi-satisfiability. T1: p T2: (~ p q) [mp~ T1 T2]: q

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsProofTheoryLemma
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a proof for theory lemma
member.remarks:
Generic proof for theory lemmas.
The theory lemma function comes with one or more parameters. The first parameter indicates the name of the theory. For the theory of arithmetic, additional parameters provide hints for checking the theory lemma. The hints for arithmetic are: - farkas - followed by rational coefficients. Multiply the coefficients to the inequalities in the lemma, add the (negated) inequalities and obtain a contradiction. - triangle-eq - Indicates a lemma related to the equivalence: (iff (= t1 t2) (and (<= t1 t2) (<= t2 t1))) - gcd-test - Indicates an integer linear arithmetic lemma that uses a gcd test.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelation
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is of relation sort.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationStore
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is an relation store
member.remarks: Insert a record into a relation. The function takes n+1 arguments, where the first argument is the relation and the remaining n elements correspond to the n columns of the relation.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsEmptyRelation
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is an empty relation

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsIsEmptyRelation
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a test for the emptiness of a relation

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationalJoin
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a relational join

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationUnion
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is the union or convex hull of two relations.
member.remarks: The function takes two arguments.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationWiden
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is the widening of two relations
member.remarks: The function takes two arguments.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationProject
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a projection of columns (provided as numbers in the parameters).
member.remarks: The function takes one argument.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationFilter
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a relation filter
member.remarks: Filter (restrict) a relation with respect to a predicate. The first argument is a relation. The second argument is a predicate with free de-Bruijn indices corresponding to the columns of the relation. So the first column in the relation has index 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationNegationFilter
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is an intersection of a relation with the negation of another.
member.remarks:
Intersect the first relation with respect to negation of the second relation (the function takes two arguments). Logically, the specification can be described by a function
target = filter_by_negation(pos, neg, columns)
where columns are pairs c1, d1, .., cN, dN of columns from pos and neg, such that target are elements in x in pos, such that there is no y in neg that agrees with x on the columns c1, d1, .., cN, dN.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationRename
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is the renaming of a column in a relation
member.remarks: The function takes one argument. The parameters contain the renaming as a cycle.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationComplement
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is the complement of a relation

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationSelect
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a relational select
member.remarks: Check if a record is an element of the relation. The function takes n+1 arguments, where the first argument is a relation, and the remaining n arguments correspond to a record.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.IsRelationClone
member.summary: Indicates whether the term is a relational clone (copy)
member.remarks: Create a fresh copy (clone) of a relation. The function is logically the identity, but in the context of a register machine allows for terms of kind to perform destructive updates to the first argument.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Expr.Index
member.summary: The de-Bruijn index of a bound variable.
member.remarks:
Bound variables are indexed by de-Bruijn indices. It is perhaps easiest to explain the meaning of de-Bruijn indices by indicating the compilation process from non-de-Bruijn formulas to de-Bruijn format.
abs(forall (x1) phi) = forall (x1) abs1(phi, x1, 0) abs(forall (x1, x2) phi) = abs(forall (x1) abs(forall (x2) phi)) abs1(x, x, n) = b_n abs1(y, x, n) = y abs1(f(t1,...,tn), x, n) = f(abs1(t1,x,n), ..., abs1(tn,x,n)) abs1(forall (x1) phi, x, n) = forall (x1) (abs1(phi, x, n+1))
The last line is significant: the index of a bound variable is different depending on the scope in which it appears. The deeper x appears, the higher is its index.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Fixedpoint.Query(Microsoft.Z3.BoolExpr)
member.summary: Query the fixedpoint solver. A query is a conjunction of constraints. The constraints may include the recursively defined relations. The query is satisfiable if there is an instance of the query variables and a derivation for it. The query is unsatisfiable if there are no derivations satisfying the query variables.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Fixedpoint.Query(Microsoft.Z3.FuncDecl[])
member.summary: Query the fixedpoint solver. A query is an array of relations. The query is satisfiable if there is an instance of some relation that is non-empty. The query is unsatisfiable if there are no derivations satisfying any of the relations.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Z3.Global
member.summary: Global functions for Z3.
member.remarks: This (static) class contains functions that effect the behaviour of Z3 globally across contexts, etc.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Global.SetParameter(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Set a global (or module) parameter, which is shared by all Z3 contexts.
member.remarks: When a Z3 module is initialized it will use the value of these parameters when Z3_params objects are not provided. The name of parameter can be composed of characters [a-z][A-Z], digits [0-9], '-' and '_'. The character '.' is a delimiter (more later). The parameter names are case-insensitive. The character '-' should be viewed as an "alias" for '_'. Thus, the following parameter names are considered equivalent: "pp.decimal-precision" and "PP.DECIMAL_PRECISION". This function can be used to set parameters for a specific Z3 module. This can be done by using [module-name].[parameter-name]. For example: Z3_global_param_set('pp.decimal', 'true') will set the parameter "decimal" in the module "pp" to true.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Global.GetParameter(System.String)
member.summary: Get a global (or module) parameter.
member.remarks: Returns null if the parameter does not exist. The caller must invoke #Z3_global_param_del_value to delete the value returned at \c param_value. This function cannot be invoked simultaneously from different threads without synchronization. The result string stored in param_value is stored in a shared location.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Global.ResetParameters
member.summary: Restore the value of all global (and module) parameters.
member.remarks: This command will not affect already created objects (such as tactics and solvers)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Global.ToggleWarningMessages(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enable/disable printing of warning messages to the console.
member.remarks: Note that this function is static and effects the behaviour of all contexts globally.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Global.EnableTrace(System.String)
member.summary: Enable tracing messages tagged as `tag' when Z3 is compiled in debug mode.
member.remarks: It is a NOOP otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Global.DisableTrace(System.String)
member.summary: Disable tracing messages tagged as `tag' when Z3 is compiled in debug mode.
member.remarks: It is a NOOP otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Model.Eval(Microsoft.Z3.Expr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Evaluates the expression in the current model.
member.remarks: This function may fail if contains quantifiers, is partial (MODEL_PARTIAL enabled), or if is not well-sorted. In this case a ModelEvaluationFailedException is thrown.
member.param: When this flag is enabled, a model value will be assigned to any constant or function that does not have an interpretation in the model.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Solver.AssertAndTrack(Microsoft.Z3.BoolExpr[],Microsoft.Z3.BoolExpr[])
member.summary: Assert multiple constraints into the solver, and track them (in the unsat) core using the Boolean constants in ps.
member.remarks: This API is an alternative to with assumptions for extracting unsat cores. Both APIs can be used in the same solver. The unsat core will contain a combination of the Boolean variables provided using and the Boolean literals provided using with assumptions.

member.remarks: This API is an alternative to with assumptions for extracting unsat cores. Both APIs can be used in the same solver. The unsat core will contain a combination of the Boolean variables provided using and the Boolean literals provided using with assumptions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Z3.Solver.Consequences(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Z3.BoolExpr},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Z3.Expr},Microsoft.Z3.BoolExpr[]@)
member.summary:
Retrieve fixed assignments to the set of variables in the form of consequences. Each consequence is an implication of the form
relevant-assumptions Implies variable = value
where the relevant assumptions is a subset of the assumptions that are passed in and the equality on the right side of the implication indicates how a variable is fixed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Solver.Proof
member.summary: The proof of the last Check(params Expr[] assumptions).
member.remarks: The result is null if Check(params Expr[] assumptions) was not invoked before, if its results was not UNSATISFIABLE, or if proof production is disabled.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Z3.Solver.UnsatCore
member.summary: The unsat core of the last Check.
member.remarks: The unsat core is a subset of Assertions The result is empty if Check was not invoked before, if its results was not UNSATISFIABLE, or if core production is disabled.
